Members of the Waxahachie ISD transportation department were put to the test this week — the fire test that is 🔥

Waxahachie Fire Chief Gary Myers provided formal instruction to the bus drivers and demonstrated fire safety before they extinguished the fires themselves.

Bus drivers practiced their routes throughout the week and underwent a variety of training that involved: evacuations, CPR, first aid assistance, EpiPen admission, and the Heimlich maneuver.

We are ready for #WISDLearners!

The Waxahachie ISD Bookmobile is en route the rest of June. This summer, students have the opportunity to keep a book rather than check one out. We thank St. Paul Episcopal Church helping provide this opportunity.

St. Paul Episcopal Church was selected to receive $20,000 worth of new books for kids by First Book, a nonprofit organization focused on providing equal access to quality education for children in need. The church donated books to the Bookmobile, libraries, and other organizations in the community.

Teachers were also able to get books for their classrooms. In the previous years, WISD had books the kids could check out from the Bookmobile. The Bookmobile was stocked enough for the first time in 2018 with giveaway books to supplement the ones that could be checked out.

If interested in donating to the Bookmobile, contact Glenna Reisner at greisner@wisd.org or 972-668-3473.

Dear Waxahachie ISD Families,

Governor Abbott announced this afternoon that all Texas public schools will be closed for students through the end of the school year. Distance learning will continue for all Waxahachie ISD students until Thursday, May 28. While this school year will not end the way any of us hoped it would, we are confident in our teachers’ abilities to end the year on a high note in their virtual classrooms.

We know that some students still have personal effects on campuses. We are developing a plan to allow for the retrieval of these items, while continuing to observe social distancing protocols. We anticipate having additional information available next week as part of our weekly communication to parents.

We thank you for your flexibility as we work together to navigate this unprecedented situation.

Respectfully,
Bonny Cain
Superintendent

The National Suicide Hotline, which is answered 24/7, is available at 1-800-273-8255.
